body: I agree. I've been having a  similar discussion on the forums but about a queue to except devices if you don't have the web UI up, maybe to auto except devices as well. A lot of people think the idea sucks, but I personally think both your idea and mine would make for a better work flow. Of corse these could be toggles for the user who does not want the option.

The question for the original post, would the location where folders get created would be per device or global? Also, what happens if a folder under the same name already exists? Do we share the existing one?

As for devices, I don't think it will happen as adding a device does not share any folders hence adds no value. And adding new device and sharing folders automatically with the newly added device is just plain damn dangerous.

I think, just auto-add the shares from "Trusted" devices.

Maybe, to add an option on the device adding, a check aquare, to mark the device as own, or trusted. Not the devices itself to be added. Just shares from a trusted devices. This is safe.

Example:
I have 2 devices: 1 PC and one Server

I share a folder "Doku" from my PC with server. On the server side, i should just once add the PC, and on adding (or later), on the device options, i should able to mark the PC device as a trusted one.

All future shared folders from my PC should automaticaly added on my server.

The location where the folder where created (in my example, server), i should maybe choose on the main options of syncthing. Or maybe in the "Sync" folder itself to add a folder "Auto-added"(this is a standard one), but, it should be great, if the user can choose one. But, on every device, should be able to choose an location. If not, the default one is selected and choosed from main options.

After this, on this main folder, if, for example, my PC syncthing name is "Main-PC", on the server side, the syncthing should create a folder with the name of devices, on the main folder.
It should look like this:

Sync/Auto-added/Main-PC/   and here, for example, my shared folder is Doku, should add this Doku shared folder there.

And yes, if the same name from same trusted device, we share this, as synthing it does now. But, here come my idea from this post:
#2070 
And, if we have this enhancement, the sorting would be wonderfull. The folder are grouped, sorted, and on the auto-adding, should take the location from sorting on the main PC.

I think it would be worth to take the time to specify all the various cases that may occur here before sitting down to implement. (But I agree this is probably worth doing.) As in, what happens when
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share a new folder
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share an existing folder
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share a new folder, then another device comes along and wants to share the same folder
- etc

I think, we should not change to much here, my proposal is:
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share a new folder - the folder should be added on the main location for trusted shares (given as default on main syncthing options), or if user give an specified location for trusted device (on device options), create this folder there, where the user has choose.
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share an existing folder - folder should be shared like it is now shared. If exist, share it, if not, create it.
- Trusted device pops in, wants to share a new folder, then another device comes along and wants to share the same folder - folder should be created, and shared with this new devices, just in case, if this devices are trusted one on the main Trusted device who pops. Other wise, it is safe to not share trusted stuff with, maybe untrusted devices.

Like this, we create a trusted network of devices and shares, perhaps, we add the option on the device options, to select, if we trust this device, or not.

I like the idea of that workflow.  if the devices share the same folder, or if a new device shares a folder with thesame name, there shoudl be an option to merge, replace, overwrite or rename the new folder so newfolder-1 for example.

Yeah, that's more better, if let the user decide what should happend with shares of Trusted devices. Maybe this options should we have on every share, to decide if merge, replace, overwrite or rename the existing folder.

This is becoming too many bells and whistles. The more options you add, or the more complexity you add the less likely it will happen, as syncthing will just become a thing with a 1000 different parameters nobody knows how to use.

@AudriusButkevicius I known, it is not easy to do all the stuff, and it is huge work, but, my idea is to have an radio button on device options, to select if this device is Trusted, and if is, then, add the shares from this device on given location (default, or selected one - this field should be changeable, or selectable, just if user click on the Trusted device button)

On the ask of @calmh , what if ... points... then, syncthing should ask the user, what to do, the 4 options (merge, replace, overwrite or rename).

And that's all. (nothing complicated for every user, if the software ask him, what to do, if...)

Like this, for example, if user have an servers around the world, it is not needed to access the servers with teamviewer, or somthing like this, and to accept every share - with this option, user need just once to add the device as Trusted, set the location, and what should happend, if ( @calmh points) - done.

Syncthing become more automatised, and more usable. Just think, if user share a couple of shares, the full internet bandwidth is used, and i need to connect with an remote desktop like teamviewer, or No Machine, the work on this remote machine is extremly slow and unusable.

With this option, user doesn't need remote desktop software anymore, to access the servers, or machine around the world, just for accept the new shares.
After reading full discussion, I do not think that this ticket is easy in any way :) Should it have "easy" label in this case?

I think the naive implementation is still easy, that does not include @Getron's bells an whistless. We have one predefined directory where, and we start sharing that folder with that device if it already exists, worst case merging its content.

@AudriusButkevicius my ideas, or proposals are not my "bells an whistless", Sorry.

This are just proposals, that, i mean, it would help many other peoples, and, if we have an automated software (Syncthing), why should it not make better, and even more easy and automated, for business directions to (like for Server farms, and Hostings people), not just for private use. Ok, it can be used on business directions to, but, every hoster, who do the Backups, and such things with Syncthing, would apreciate the automation to.

Like the version 0.12.x with pausing devices, improved refreshing time (allmost no pause time on refreshing now, wonderfull), and all of this ideas are realised, and every person now is happy to have this, it works wonderfull. Maybe, not everyone need the pausing devices, for example, but, the function is there, and "if" someone need it, it is there - and this is wonderfull, it works great.

Unfortunatly, i'm not so good on programming, and can not help as much as i wish. Therefore, i give just ideas, and proposals, and this, are not "bells an whistless", this are just proposals how it maybe works at best the proposal.

Anyway, would thank an all of devs for time spended for having a wonderfull software.

I think this is a duplicate of #1839.
I want like the idea and would like to see it implemented.
Perhaps I will give it a go once I try my hand at GO.

issue.title: automatic acceptance of syncs

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

issue.body:
My use case is:
-  Two large NAS boxes on two US coasts
-  Various laptops, desktops, and servers which need to be backed up to each coast

Ideally, I would like to have a way to say, "If this machine creates a sync, put it here, and if the names conflict, just handle it" so "client" machines can add and remove syncs without any remote access to the NAS boxes, nor without any intervention by another human.
